here we're not asking for payment information any sort of credentials the
beauty of the Kindle Fire platform is that when you take it out of the box the first thing you do is log into your

conversion as we'll see here on the next slide some of you may have seen this
this is a study that flurry did a couple of months back looking at a basket of best-selling games and apps that existed
on iOS on kindle fire and on google play and looking at the revenue that those
apps were deriving from each of the platforms over that same time period and what they saw was that for every buck
that the apps for making on iTunes on iOS those same apps for making 89 cents
on kindle fire and the amazon appstore verses 23 cents in google play and so
this was encouraging early in our life cycle we're working hard on this and want the number to be even higher but it
shows that that friction free experience is working similarly this is another
study from from TinyCo they launched this game tiny village that you saw in
the email simultaneously across all three platforms and found that the the
average revenue per user on kindle fire again was very strong if you look at the bottom this one is even better than the

making a buck 80 on the Amazon devices including kindle fire versus 65 cents in
Google Play so this notion of mean buying experience to be through the
sdk again is working a couple of quote quotes here I want to read them but but
we also worked very hard to make the in-app purchasing API very simple most
developers tell us that they can get up and running playing with it in a couple hours and in a typical implementation is

some of the results this slide shows offers in app purchase offers which
which are in orange and then the actual units ordered in those same apps which
are in blue there's some interesting things that emerged here first as you might expect there are there's a
clustering of both offers and purchasing down at 99 cents but what's a little
more surprising is that there are plenty of offers at higher price points we cut the slide off at 999 but you can see
that there's two dollars very popular for 9999 developers are experimenting
with higher price point items in app then when you look at what customers are actually buying I think it's surprising
to see that the majority of the purchases are not actually at 99 cents there is good activity there but we
actually see more purchasing at a buck 99 and also at 499 very popular price
point almost the same and so we there are a couple of things that are going on here based on our conversations with
developers first there's a little bit of the traditional good better best retailing going on in that if you
provide for example different baskets of superpowers you may find that customers
don't want to go for the cheapest option don't want to go for the more its most expensive option land a little bit land
in the middle but that middle ground is higher than if you had just started with one offer only at 99 cents so that's
interesting now the other thing is that developers are getting more and more sophisticated
about having a variety of offers and presenting the right offer to the right
customer at the right time you can identify the users that are more deeply engaged with your app and game and you
can present them with maybe a larger basket of goods that cost more at the right time in their engagement lifecycle
they're willing to buy and so that's what what we're seeing here on this this slide here's another interesting one on
the horizontal access we have the number of in-app purchase items that were
available for sale in a given app on the vertical access we have the number of orders per customer that came out of

what we believe we're seeing is that the more sophisticated developers that have

the revenue occurs after the customer has had the game for 30 days and so
developing that relationship strategy being able to keep the customers coming

with other gamers and also to connect with the games that they have on their devices more frequently and in more
exciting ways provides a number of different features you can find friends
through the game circle network or by connecting to Facebook through game
circle you can keep track of your high scores and your achievements in the

you download Skylanders you don't have to start over you start right at level 36 as a customer you don't have to do

engagement is one we announced relatively recently called free time we
noticed with the first generation kindle fire that there were significant numbers
of children that we're actually using these devices this is the so-called pass back use case you're in the car and the

devices we built of new experience for children from the ground up and it's
called kindle freetime the idea here is that as a parent you can create profiles
for each of your children I've got you know Jake coos 10 and Sarah who's six
and then for each of those profiles you can select from the content that you is
the parent have purchased which pieces of content you want available for each of your children you drop those pieces
of content into a secure play pen area and then before you hand the device to
your child you basically turn on the playpen and your child can use anything that you've put in that play pen forum
but they can't get out right they can't buy new things and so this is this works
for books and music and videos and apps and games all of that is accessible based on
what you decide as a parent the name free time comes from another great feature you can also control the number
of minutes that you allow your children to spend consuming each type of content per day so you might say it's okay for
both of my kids to spend as much time reading as they want but I'm going to cap their gameplay at 30 minutes each
day and when you hit the end of that timer basically you can't open any more games the game the kids in closes so
powerful experience and again the reason we think it's important is parents are
going to love this we believe and that's going to drive them to discover and
download more content that's appropriate for children that's going to drive more usage and again turn the flywheel of
both discovery and engagement and monetization a few other points I would
highlight just down at the bottom of this slide in addition to making it
simple to drive discovery we've also tried to make it very safe for children so you can't buy things when you're in
the free time playpen location-based services are turned off social sharing is turned off you know it's really
designed to be a safe protected environment and Patera so that parents can just give the device to the kids and
not worry about it okay let's turn
towards kindle fire we often get asked you know how do i how do i make a great app for this kindle fire platform and so
we have a couple of thoughts here first
thing before we get to kindle fire specifics it's obviously important just to have a great app or game that's
platform that's agnostic of the platform and we we see this happening typically in in three or four different ways the
apps that customers prefer either one do something better than all other apps in the class that's provide great utility
whether it's touchdown for email or office we pro for reading and editing office documents as are good examples their second way to be a great app or
game is to provide great value Pandora obviously amazing music service for free for most people although you can pay to
eliminate the ads it doesn't always mean free so ocean house media has licensed
the dr. Seuss properties and they have these fantastic interactive children's book apps married to you have animations
they're not free there are a couple of bucks but when you think of the utility of that the value they're providing
versus the cost of a typical paper children's book it's amazing value and so that's resonating really well with
the parents that are using these devices being distinctive obviously you can
create a new genre that's great we also find that in genres that have existed for a long time developers that can put
some sort of unique spin on it whether it's through the implementation of the creative some aspect of the game play
those tend to take off and in the last point is also around hooking the
customers because there are so many apps and games out there it's so easy for customers to try them it's critical that
in that first five maybe it's three to five minutes you find a way to hook those customers and so these these apps
plans for zombies and Temple Run have basically tutorials on steroids that teach you how to use the game and by the
time you're done with them you're excited to continue and so that's that's the best practice another thing again
just in that sort of generic making a great app is is thinking carefully about which business model is right paid apps
do still work in many situations when intellectual property is strong and
recognized when the developer has good brand equity and wants to build on that consumers are willing to pay upfront
certain classes of apps are just simply expected to be more on the page genre
for example a lot of the reference medical etc so paid apps that that is still a viable business model for the
appropriate situation freemium tends to be a good solution when some of those
things are not true but it's also important that freemium titles are somehow progressive in nature so that
there is additional content there's a reason for the customer to fall in love with the story and want to either
accelerate their ability to move through it or to enhance their experience somehow and so it's important to think
about that if you're thinking about moving towards the freemium model last thing I'll point out here is that you
know subscription anzar have existed for a long time in
content categories app categories where that is been the model offline for example periodical apps we're
increasingly seeing developers start to experiment with this in other categories like gaming still very nascent but the
adoption by consumers appears to be fairly strong and so I think it's an interesting trend for us to watch and
think about so with those two high-level points made now we turn to again still
not thinking about kindle fire but actually just making a great app for tablets I've got here a use case for
Evernote this is what their phone app looked like when it was stretched to 7
inches that's the before and then the adaptations they made for Kindle Fire HD
on the right that's the after and so in the before view you can see that basically what they had was top-level
navigational structure as the whole home screen of the app you had to end it
before you could engage with the app you had to say this is what I want to do the layout that they went to on the right
hand side there's a number of interesting things first they took that navigation and they kept it in the the
dark gray pain but they also they implemented a hierarchy to bring forward
the most important use cases creating a new note etc taking a screenshot note
also that they elevated a couple of use cases they found more popular on tablets to that premier status and that's using
audio and attaching making an attachment so a little bit of intelligence around how consumers were using tablet apps
differently than phones then if you look at the green sub navigational bar at the top and the after slide those are
additional navigational options that they took out of the Android settings menu and put up at this top level of the
app so they basically eliminated a drill down step for the customer because they have more real estate and then finally
on the right hand side they took the most common user stories seeing the
actual notes that are that have been created most frequently and actually put those right on the top page of the app
so those those pains slide those vertical pain slide and as a consumer you can
literally get right into the action without having to do navigation as you had to on the phone app so pretty these
are these are not terribly complicated changes but they have a huge impact on the customer experience for this this
app and are appropriate for the tablet use case it's this type of thing that we recommend that the developers think about for kindle fire after all is said
and done the the leap from those previous three slides to optimization for the device is actually very small
things that most developers need to think about are making sure that they're
aware of the the specifications and hardware and software capabilities of the device for example they're not
phones and so need to make sure that you're adapting for that not all of them
have cameras although that the HD models do and so making sure that if your app or game uses a camera that I that
feature is either removed or fails gracefully one thing that's interesting around tablets is making sure that the
apps and games are listening carefully to the sensors for the orientation of the device these devices the HD devices
have cameras in the bezel the way they fit into the case that's going to drive consumers to orient the tablet in a
certain way want to make sure that the app and game is aware of that by reading the sensors so a little bit different
than then the phone use case where there's a cameras on the back of the device or it's at the top if there is
one so simple things like that but important for the user experience focusing on fluidity and performance are
important with the HD devices in particular we're finding the developers are are sending increasingly large apps
into the system high-definition assets to make sure that the gameplay is
fantastic for example and that's great but also is important to get a hold of
the emulators which we'll talk about and with the devices themselves to tune the performance make sure that it's snappy
also means that startup times can be a little bit longer and the worst thing is
for the customer to just sit and wait and wonder if things are working and so the more savvy developers have come up
with creative and interesting splash screens to get things going so that the customer knows that something is
happening and and don't feel like they're waiting for a long time so small considerations to adapt for Kindle Fire
specifically but but not too far of a leap so here's an example of need for
speed on the 8.9 inch device plays fantastically and you know they've done
